newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate plunges to new post-crisis low.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate plunges to new post-crisis low.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates closed down 110 basis points to 18.30 percent on Monday, their lowest rate since the peso devaluation crisis of December 1994.
Traders said rates fell due to ample market liquidity, despite the fact that U.S. investors were absent from the market due to Presidents Day.
"Although we were expecting a slow session due to the absence of U.S. dealers, the market was awash in liquidity again," a trader said.
"A stable peso and the outlook for lower inflation still seem to be driving rates down," he added.
Benchmark 48-hour peso contracts closed 2.5 centavos softer at 7.7930/7.7960 per dollar.

Lower secondary rates led several dealers to forecast falls of up to 100 basis points in bellwether 28-day Cetes rates at Tuesday's primary central bank auction. This would also take benchmark interest rates down to their lowest level since the 1994 crisis.
Overnight rates on bank paper meanwhile fell 25 basis points to 20.35 percent.
A sign of surplus market liquidity was central bank participation in the session, where it drained 1.154 billion pesos from the system.
Liquidity of 204 million pesos was scheduled to return to the system on Tuesday. Nonetheless, traders said government spending estimated at three billion pesos would increase liquidity considerably.
